May 6: May 6th, 1933: The Deutsche Studentenschaft (German Student Union) attacks Magnus Hirschfeld’s Institut für Sexualwissenscaft (Institute of Sexology). Many of its books would be burned, and its discoveries and histories would be lost.
May 5: May 5th, 1260: Kublai Khan becomes ruler of the Mongol Empire.
May 4: May 4th, 1886: The Haymarket Affair. A large labor rally in Chicago, Illinois by the Federation of Organized Trades and Labor Unions is disrupted by a protestor throwing a bomb at police following police brutality and murder the day before. It erupts into riots. By the end, 8 police died and 60 were injured. 4 protestors died, more than 70 were injured, and over 100 were arrested.
May 3: May 3rd, 752: King Yaxun B'alam IV (Bird Jaguar IV) of the Maya city Yaxchilan assumes the throne.
May 2: May 2nd, 1885: Cree and Assiniboine warriors win the Battle of Cut Knife, their largest victory over Canadian forces during the North-West Rebellion.
May 1: May 1st, 1886: Rallies throughout the United States demanding an eight-hour workday begin. May 1st is celebrated as International Workers’ Day in many countries.

May 1st, 1946: The Pilbara strike, a strike by indigenous Australian pastoral workers for human rights, fair wages, and better working conditions, begins. It involved more than 800 workers walking off from their jobs and lasted for over three years.Strikers were met with violence and unlawful arrest but ultimately won their demands. The 1946 Pilbara strike is remembered as the first and one of the longest industrial strikes by Aboriginal people since colonization.
April 30: April 30th, 1937: The Commonwealth of the Philippines holds a plebiscite for Philipino women on whether they should be extended the right to suffrage; over 90% would vote in the affirmative.
April 29: April 29th, 1429: Joan of Arc arrives to relieve the Siege of Orléans.
April 28: April 28th, 1402: Nezahualcoyotl, a Mexica/Acolhuan philosopher and tlatoani, is born.
April 27: April 27th, 1521: Portuguese explorer Ferdinand Magellan is killed by chief Lapulapu and other natives in the Philippines at the Battle of Mactan.
April 26: April 26th, 1963: Amendments to the Constitution of Libya transformed the United Kingdom of Libya into one national unity, the Kingdom of Libya. It also allows female suffrage.
April 25: April 25th, 1974: A leftist military coup called the Carnation Revolution overthrows the authoritarian-conservative Portuguese government. It results in the Portuguese transtition to democracy and decolonization of Portuguese territories in Africa.
April 4: April 4th, 1769: Georges Cuvier delivers the world’s first paleontology lecture.
March 2: March 2nd, 1937L The Steel Workers Organizing Committee signs a collective bargaining agreement with U.S. Steel, leading to unionization of the United States steel industry.
February 26: February 26th, 1365: The Ava Kingdom and the royal city of Ava were founded by King Thado Minbya.
February 25: February 25th, 1870: Hiram Rhodes Revels, a Republican from Mississippi, is sworn into the United States Senate, becoming the first African American ever to sit in Congress.
February 20: February 20th, 1756: Angelica Schuyler Church was born.
January 15: January 15th, 1908: The Alpha Kappa Alpha sorority becomes the first Greek-letter organization founded and established by African American college women.
December 9: December 9th, 1922: Gabriel Narutowicz is elected the first president of Poland.
November 9: November 9th, 1867: Tokugawa shogunate hands power back to the Emperor of Japan, starting the Meiji Restoration.
November 4: November 4th, 1960: Dr. Jane Goodall observes chimpanzees creating tools, the first-ever observation in non-human animals.
September 30: September 30th, 1765 Mexican priest and revolutionary José María Morelos is born.
